name: Archi StyledHtml module
documentation:
• You have designed something, you have the Archimate model on it. But you have to create a documentation in the form requested by your client.
  • You are designing something complex. You want to make sure that you have thought about all aspects and interdependencies.
  • You work with junior architects or developers. You are tired of checking their models for trivial errors and omissions.
  • You are doing detailed design, and it is boring to do the trivial task of converting the model to config file by hand.
If any of the above happens, this module and the underlying concepts are developed for you. This module makes possible to
  • define and document enterprise architecture policies
  • check architecture models against those policies
  • define documentation styles for various stakeholders, and generate those documentations from the model
  • generate configuration and code directly from the model
This model tries to fulfill multiple purposes: - Show how Archimate can be used in the goovernance of IT - Document the styledhtml Archi module - Serve as an example for both of the above - The webpage of the styledhtml module is generated from it. See http://archistyledhtml.sourceforge.net/ You can find user documentation in the Use Cases section.

elements.name: Archi community
elements.documentation: Anyone who does anything related to Archi belongs here

elements.name: Archi users
elements.documentation: The users of Archi. All and any of them.

elements.name: Archi developers
elements.documentation: Everyone who develops archi or one of the modules belonging to it.

elements.name: Download Archi
elements.documentation: With any web browser from the Archi download site.

elements.name: Archi download site
elements.documentation:
You can download Archi at
http://archi.cetis.ac.uk/download.html

elements.name: Download the StyledHtml package
elements.documentation: Using any web browser, from the StyledHtml download site.

elements.name: StyledHtml download site
elements.documentation: It is at https://sourceforge.net/projects/archistyledhtml/files/

elements.name: Install Archi
elements.documentation:
See http://archi.cetis.ac.uk/download/latest/Archi%20User%20Guide.pdf
"Installing and Launching Archi"

elements.name: install the StyledHtml package
elements.documentation:
Just unzip the package in the install directory of Archi.

Further info for troubleshooting, consider it only if something goes wrong:

The package contains two jar files, which go to the "plugins" directory.
The Archi directory should already contain a "plugins" directory.
You don't have to unzip the jar files. If you see new directories with names like "bin" and "META-INF" then you have managed to unzip the jars...

elements.name: start Archi
elements.documentation:
If you were already running archi this is the time to exit and restart it.
You start Archi in the usual way, see
http://archi.cetis.ac.uk/download/latest/Archi%20User%20Guide.pdf

elements.name: Check the module
elements.documentation:
You should have
- a "Styled Export" tab in Edit/Preferences,
- a "File/Export/Model to Styled Html" menu entry, and
- a "File/Export/Model to rich format" menu entry

elements.name: installation
elements.documentation: This is how you install the StyledHtml module for Archi

elements.name: Checkout the provided styles
elements.documentation:
In Edit/Preferences/Styled Export
Push "Install Provided Styles".
Choose the directory you want to export the provided styles.

elements.name: Configure the style used
elements.documentation:
You may want to checkout the provided styles before doing this.

Press the modify button on the stylesheet location.
Give the stylesheet location in the file dialog.
Navigate to the stylesheet drectory, and choose the file named "style.xslt".

elements.name: Configure output directory
elements.documentation:
Use the modify button and the file dialog to designate the directory you want the output be.
If you check the "Don't ask for location" checkbox, then styled export won't ask you for the location when exporting. If you don't check it, the directory you have given here will be the default.

elements.name: Create your own style
elements.documentation:
You can create your own style using XSLT.
Create a directory, place a file called "style.xslt" in it.
The input of style.xslt is a rich format model, the output is "index.html".
The contents of the directory containing style.xslt will be recursively copyed to the output directory, so you can place css, images, etc to the style directory.

There are also more complex scenarios, see FIXME to learn about them.
You can use one of the provided styles as a starting point.

elements.name: Configuration
elements.documentation: This is how you configure the StyledHtml module to be able to create nice reports with it.

elements.name: Create a report
elements.documentation:
You want to configure the style used and maybe the output dir before you do this.
You use the Styled Export menu entry.
If you did not check "Don't ask for location", then a file dialog wil appear, where you can define the output directory.
If the directory already exists (and you did not check the "Don't ask for location" checkbox), a dialog will appear asking whether to overwrite it.

elements.name: Edit your model
elements.documentation:
You do it in the usual way in Archi.
See http://archi.cetis.ac.uk/download/latest/Archi%20User%20Guide.pdf

elements.name: Preview output
elements.documentation:
Using the browser you can preview the report.
Just point to index.html in the output dir.

elements.name: Preview the export log
elements.documentation:
The export log appearsh in an eventlog window. It is most useful if you have a policy related to the report. You can use it to remediate inconsitencies in your model. Clicking on the links will focus on the element which have the problem.

Hint: By clicking analysis on the properties tab, you will see the views where the element participates in, and the relations of it. You can navigate to the view by clicking on it.

elements.name: Problem occured
elements.documentation:
If there is something wrong in the process, a problem report dialog will appear.
See Troubleshooting for this case.

elements.name: Look at the problem report dialog
elements.documentation: The problem report dialog should give you some hint on what happened

elements.name: Look at the application log
elements.documentation:
See application log file for the location of application log file.
Look at the end of it for any hint.

elements.name: application log file
elements.documentation:
In the installation directory of Archi there is a file called Archi.ini
Look at the definition of osgi.instance.area, looking something like this:
-Dosgi.instance.area=@user.home/uk.ac.bolton/Archi

The @user.home here is your home directory.
Within the directory defined by osgi.instance.area there is a file called .metadata/.log

This is the log file.

elements.name: look at stdout/stderr
elements.documentation:
If still no solution, look at the stdout/stderr of the application.
In unix, you should start it from a terminal window to achieve it, or look at the .xsession-error or similar file. See the configuration of your desktop for further details.
In windows? Dunno.

elements.name: Analyse problem
elements.documentation: You can look at several places to figure out what have happened.

elements.name: Problem identified
elements.documentation:
If you could identify the cause of the problem, you are happy.
Now the next step is to remediate or report the problem.

elements.name: No clue
elements.documentation: If you don't know what caused the problem, or how to solve this, it is time to report it.

elements.name: Remediate problem
elements.documentation:
If you can remediate the problem (e.g. it is a problem with a stylesheet or policy you have created, or there is a known workaround for a known bug),
you do it, and you became very happy.
If the fix needs something more (it is an unknown bug, or needs a yet unknown fix or change in the source code), please report it.

elements.name: report problem
elements.documentation: You can report any problem through https://sourceforge.net/p/archistyledhtml/tickets/

elements.name: Being happy
elements.documentation: Problem solved, congratulation.

elements.name: sketchtotable
elements.documentation: the sketchtotable style should be brought back to shape and documented

elements.name: define the objectClass by direct property
elements.documentation: An objectClass can be directly defined for an element by setting an objectClass property with the value as the objectClass name

elements.name: define the objectClass by indirect property
elements.documentation: Any property having a : in its name implies that the string before the : is the objectClass of the containing element. For example by setting report:part to all on a folder, we actually telling that the folder have a report objectClass, and a report specific attribute named part with the value all.

elements.name: define the objectClass with a Group or Folder
elements.documentation: By setting the associatedObjectClass property of a Group or a Folder, we declare that all elements in it are belonging to the objectClass named by the value of the property.

elements.name: define the objectClass by specialisation
elements.documentation: this does not work yet. If object A is of the objectClass Template then all objects which specialisation of A will have the objectClass named after the name of A.

elements.name: objectClass
elements.documentation:
The primary abstraction of the policy is the objectClass element.
An objectClass describes a concept derived from either a builtin archimate element, or another objectClass: the ancestor of the objectClass.

We can define the objectClass of an archimate element in one of the following ways:

- add a property where the name is "objectClass" and the value is the name of the objectclass
- add a property where the name is in the form <class>:<property>, where <class> is the name of the objectclass, and <property> is the name of one of the properties of the objectclass. The value vill be the value of the objectClass property.
- create a Group in a view, with the property named "associatedObjectClass". The value of the property should be the name of the objectClass. All the elements within the group (including the nested ones) will belong to the objectClass

The policy related to the objectclass will help to check the model for structure and content, and also makes creating reports and generating configurations easier.
One of the examples of this is that the policy for this model can be generated from this model, and the generated policy can be used to check that this model is indeed conforms to the policy which is generated from it :)

elements.name: parent
elements.documentation:
The ancestor of the objectClass.
The objectclass have all the properties of its non-builtin ancestors.

The ancestor is represented by a tag named 'ancestor' having an attribute named 'class' with the value of the ancestor class name in the policy file.

elements.name: there is a specialisation relationship from the ancestor to the objectClass
abstract
elements.documentation:
If "true", the objectClass is merely used for the purpose of instantiating properties for other objectclasses. It should not be directly instantiated in a model.

The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

FIXME: check for this is not implemented yet.

elements.name: attrib
elements.documentation: The id of an attribute belonging to the objectClass

elements.name: A composition relationship points from here to the attribute
attribute
elements.documentation: The attribute is used to describe a attribute of an objectClass. You can define a attribute value either by giving the value to a property named classname:attributename to an object, or by using a model structure defined by the defaults of the given attribute.

elements.name: type
elements.documentation:
The type of the property.
It will be used when an xsd is generated from the policy.
The xsd in turn will be used to check the values given.

The property is represented by the attribute named 'type' in the policy file.

elements.name: minOccurs
elements.documentation:
How much time the property should be occur minimally in the objectClass.
If no such property, then the value is deemed to be 1.
It will be used when an xsd is generated from the policy.
The xsd in turn will be used to check the values given.

The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

elements.name: maxOccurs
elements.documentation:
How much time the property should be occur maximally in the objectClass.
If no such property, then there is no limit.
It will be used when an xsd is generated from the policy.
The xsd in turn will be used to check the values given.

The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

elements.name: structural
elements.documentation:
If the value of this property is "true", then the property is structural:
The value will be generated by a default associated to it, and it is an error to enter the value into the model through some properties.

FIXME: this check is not implemented yet.

The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

elements.name: def
elements.documentation:
The id of a default related to the attribute.

The property is represented by a tag named 'type' in the policy file.

elements.name: A composition relation points to the default from the attribute
default
elements.documentation:
The default is used to describe how a property will get its default value if we have not given anything.
It is useful to
- describe and enforce structural relationships within the model
- give default value to a property

This attribute should be entered as a property.

elements.name: description
elements.documentation:
The description of the default.

Ideally it describes how to give a value to the property through model structure, or what is the default value of the property, and why it is so.


The description is represented by the tag named 'description' in the policy file.

elements.name: name of the parent node + the documentation of the parent node
elements.documentation: By convention the 'how' and 'what' are described in the archimate element name, and the 'why' in its documentation.

elements.name: order
elements.documentation:
The order in which the defaults are evaluated.
The default evaluation goes in the following way:
1. i:=0
2. if there is a default with order i, then try it. else stop.
3. if the default gave back a value, then stop.
4. i:= i+1
5. continue from 2.

Beware: if defaults are not numbered sequentially from zero, then some of them might not be tried.
The reason of this behaviour that the sequence of getting the attributes from the policy programatically is not guaranteed to be the same as they are described there.

The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

elements.name: select
elements.documentation:
The xpath expression to be evaluated to get the value of the property.
If multi="true", then the result should be a nodeset, else a string.

The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

elements.name: multi
elements.documentation:
Whether the select will return multiple values.
If set to "true", then for each item in the nodelist returned by the select, a different property will be generated.

The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.
FIXME: there should be a "type" attribute instead, defaulting to string, with the following possible values:
string: default functionality
multi: multi="true"
structured: works like xsl:copy-of

elements.name: always
elements.documentation:
Whether to try to always apply the default, even when there is already such a property.

The property is represented by the attribute with the same name in the policy file.

elements.name: ArchimateObjectClass
elements.documentation:
An objectclass predefined by Archi.
This does not show up in the policy file explicitly. Used to have a starting point to generate/document the objectClass hierarchy.

elements.name: abstractNamed
elements.documentation: This is an abstract class, so we don't need to define the name and description property for all objectClasses.

elements.name: description
elements.documentation:
The description of the objectClass.

The description is represented by the tag named 'description' in the policy file.

elements.name: name
elements.documentation:
name of the objectClass

The name is represented by an attribute named 'name' of the objectClass in the policy file.

elements.name: The server which realizes the application

elements.name: Salary app

elements.documentation:
64 kb RAM C<
There is a trick here: a composition relation points from this to this. (dragged another instance of the node to the view, created a composition between the two instances, then removed the instance)

elements.name: 3. Business Specification Acceptance
elements.documentation:
The act of accepting the business specification.

The actor(s) related to this process step is deliberately missing, so you can have an error in the policy check output as an example.

elements.name: 2. Business Specification Overview
elements.documentation: Overview of the business specification.

elements.name: 1. Creating business specification
elements.documentation: The process in which the business specification is created.
Initial version
Added new version number and specialisation relation to it.

This module works with Archi 2.0.0.
There is an event log window. It displays the warnings and errors when exporting the model.If a message contains a link to an element, you can jump to that element by clicking on the link.
major restructure, now we have two modules. The new one is the browser modul originally developed by Phil to support the event log window.
You can find user documentation and use cases under Use Cases.
The Extended Archimate methodology is documented under introduction.
The created report is shown in a browser window.
The followup release of Archi 2.2.0, featuring the new Motivation and Implementation & Migration extensions

elements.name: archimate:BusinessCollaboration
elements.documentation: See the archimate standard at http://www.opengroup.org/archimate/doc/ts_archimate/

elements.name: archimate:Folder
elements.documentation: A folder containing some elements of a model.

elements.documentation: See the archimate standard at http://www.opengroup.org/archimate/doc/ts_archimate/

elements.documentation: A plateau

elements.documentation: The archimate model.

elements.name: archimate:Node
elements.documentation: A Node as defined by Archimate

elements.name: archimate:ApplicationComponent
elements.documentation: Application Component

elements.name: report
elements.documentation: folder properties to parameterize reports

elements.name: part
elements.documentation: The name of the report part for which this folder should be displayed

elements.name: DocumentVersion
elements.documentation: A Document version.

elements.name: releasedate
elements.documentation: The release date of the document version

elements.name: versionnumber
elements.documentation: The version number of the document version

elements.name: authorid
elements.documentation: The id of the author

elements.name: A Realisation relation should point from the author to the document version
GovernanceStep
elements.documentation:
A governance process step.
It is used to describe the related actors by the documentcontrol style.

elements.name: state
elements.documentation: The state of the step

elements.name: actor
elements.documentation: An actor involved in the step.

elements.name: A used by relationship points from the author to the process step
OrganisationalUnit
elements.documentation: An organisational unit.

elements.name: OrganisationalPerson
elements.documentation: A person belonging to an organisation

elements.name: position
elements.documentation:
position of the person

FIXME: should have a default which computes it by the composition relation with the organisation (property or line text), because it should actually change by organisation for the same person.

elements.name: organisation
elements.documentation: The (primary) organisation of the person.

elements.name: More organisational units contains (Composition) the person, and one of the relations have a property with "primary" property.
elements.documentation:
When the person belongs to more organisational units, one of them should be the primary one.
It is designated by a property added to the composition relationship.

elements.name: Exactly one organisational unit contains (Composition) the person.
elements.documentation: When the person belongs to one organisational unit, then this organisational unit is its primary organisation.

elements.name: memberOf
elements.documentation:
The organisations of the person.

FIXME: all Business Collaborations and Business Roles should have been listed here

elements.name: Organisational units containing (Composition) the person.
elements.documentation: All the organisational units which contain the person.

elements.name: default style
elements.documentation:
The default style gives us the same result as the built-in File/Report/HTML... menu in Archi.
It is a flat enumeration of elements by architecture level and element type, followed by the diagrams

The example report made from this example model can be found at http://archistyledhtml.sourceforge.net/default.html

elements.name: structured style
elements.documentation:
The report contains the objects and diagrams in the same structure as they are in the model, with a table of contents.

For each folder it displays
- any diagram in the folder
- any element in the folder
- the contents of the contained folders recursively

If you do not want an item (folder/element) to be displayed (e.g. no important information in the relations), you can add the report:hide attribute with a calue which evaluates to true (1 okay) to the folder. warning: in the future this might be changed to be report:part=hide.

The output might not be nice, but at least easy to overview.
Cosmetic fixups are welcome, I am not good at visual design.

This is also an example of how one can use xslt to generate a html, and css to give a look to it.

You can find an example report output at http://archistyledhtml.sourceforge.net/

elements.name: sketchtotable style
elements.documentation:
This report style is to present the result of a brainstorming session using Nominal Group Technique (NGT).

See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nominal_group_technique for NGT.

How to use Archi during the session:

 - Create a Sketch. Assign a property to it with the key 'objectClass', and value 'NGTresult'.

 - In the "sharing ideas" step record each idea on a sticky.

 - In the "group discussion" step organize stickies hierarchically. If idea A is considered to be a subset/instance of idea B, then place A within B. If A and B are in the same group, place them inside the same (possibly newly created) sticky. 

 - In the "voting and ranking" step place an element (we have only actor right now, it is okay) on the sketch. Each vote is represented by a connection between the element and a "main" sticky (which is not inside another one0.

Do not use connections for other purposes.


Presentation:

For each sketch having the NGTresult objectClass, a table is written.
Rows represent a "main" sticky. The first cell contains the ranking (number of connections associated with) the idea.
In the second cell you can find the content of the sticky. If there are more stickies inside the main one, they are presented hierarchically in a list.


possible enhancements (notify me if you want them, and I may implement it)

- We might have a label for a sticky. E.g. if there is a "::" in the contents, then everything before it is the label. it could be displayed in a column.
- We might allow connections between elements, by designating one connection type to votes (so the others could be used for other purposes.
- (It needs additional code in Archi) The stickies in the sketch could be automatically turned into archimate elements. By using properties cleverly, even a mapping from sticky color to folder and element type could be done. Note that Phil seems to work on it.

elements.name: documentcontrol style
elements.documentation:
An example style mplementing the usual document control functionality, and the objectclasses.

Lists the versions sorted by version number, then the actors used for two named process steps.

This example contains a postprocessor written in python.
It generates a policy file called "newpolicy.xml".

See http://archistyledhtml.sourceforge.net/documentcontrol.html for an example.

elements.name: Properties tab
elements.documentation: It is at Edit/Preferences/Styled Export.

elements.name: file dialog
elements.documentation:
This is where you choose files and directories.

FIXME: there are some minor usage problems with this widget which should be fixed.

elements.name: problem report
elements.documentation:
A dialog stating the problem.
If such a dialog appears, some additional information may be available in the stdout/stderr of the application, the application log, or the eventlog.
See troubleshooting for details.

elements.name: browser window
elements.documentation: The browser is used to display event log and report output

elements.name: xmlitem
elements.documentation: An xml item describes a model, entity or attribute.

elements.name: parent
elements.documentation: the parent of the item

elements.name: type
elements.documentation:
type of the item
- model
- entity
- attribute
reference

elements.name: name
elements.documentation: the name of the item

elements.name: value
elements.documentation: value of the item

elements.name: label
elements.documentation: used for access control

elements.name: report:part
elements.documentation: This property tells us which part of the model to gerenate. There is a corresponding stylesheet parameter named part. The documentation by default will recursively contain all elements in folders below the marked model/folder (see also the noroot stylesheet parameter).

elements.name: report:role
elements.documentation: This parameter is to restrict the visibility of some parts of the model, based on the target audience. There is a corresponding stylesheet parameter named role. The objects and/or folders marked with report:role will be generated only if the stylesheet parameter's value is the same as the property's value. It is not possible to use more than one role neither as a property nor as a stylesheet parameter. If you would need this, please file a bug report. If you also want to handle diagrams properly, you have to utilize the split xml stylesheet. There is a corresponding xml tag to mark parts of the element documentation named only, with the role attribute, used in the obvious way.

elements.name: from-folder
elements.documentation:
This property holds the id of a folder, and folders can be marked with it.
All elements from the referenced folder will be added to the documentation of the referring folder, but diagrams, sketches and folders.

Yes, it is the id of the model element which is a bit complicated to figure out (you should look at the model's xml). It does not change if you change the name of the element, and it is not ambigous. If you can come up with a better way, and you actually need it then file a bug report.

elements.name: copy-image
elements.documentation: inserts a diagram to where it is referenced

elements.name: part
elements.documentation: See the report:part model property.

elements.name: noroot
elements.documentation: If this parameter is set, then the folders below the one marked with the report:part property will be documented.

elements.name: role
elements.documentation: Please see the report:role property.

elements.name: Silly question
elements.documentation:
After the folder is choosen, Archi asks whether you want to delete this directory.
It a bug, ignore it

elements.name: Move around
elements.documentation:
The ability to move objects freely in the model's hierarchy.
This supports the structured display of views and objects belonging to that view.
It is used by not just the structured style, which is a base for the majority of report styles used in real life.
A patch is already submitted

elements.name: Enterprise repository
elements.documentation:
An enterprise repository would be very nice.
It could be done using CDO. There is already a proof of concept code, but a major restructure would be needed.

elements.name: Persistence layer
elements.documentation:
Currently the whole code mixes business logic and GUI.
It should be sorted out to be able to correctly support batch report generation and enterprise repository.
